article.title: A short note on Godbersen's Conjecture

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the coefficient V(K<sub>i1</sub>,...,K<sub>in</sub>) represent in equation (1)?
choices: The volume of a single convex body K<sub>i1</sub>
The sum of the volumes of convex bodies K<sub>i1</sub>,...,K<sub>in</sub>
The **mixed volume** of convex bodies K<sub>i1</sub>,...,K<sub>in</sub>
The surface area of the convex body formed by Σλ<sub>i</sub>K<sub>i</sub>

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the upper bound proposed by Godbersen\'s conjecture for the mixed volume V(K[j], -K[n-j]) of a convex body K?
What is the main result shown by Corollary 4?
choices: Godbersen\'s conjecture holds true for all convex bodies.
The mixed volumes V(K[j],-K[n-j]) are always equal for all j.
**On average**, the Godbersen conjecture holds true for convex bodies.
The difference body of a convex body K has the same volume as K.

multiple_choice_question.text: According to Lemma 6 (Rogers and Shephard), what is the relationship between the volume of a convex body T, its projection onto a subspace E (denoted by P<sub>E</sub>T), and its section with E (denoted by T∩E)?
